Authors:
Rongrong Wang, Xinyu Li, Jacek Szwedo, Adam Stroinski,
Aiping Liang, Thierry Bourgoin
Title:
Testing Tropiduchini Stål, 1866 (Hemiptera: Tropiduchidae)
monophyly, a young inter-tropical taxa of mainly insular species:
taxonomy, distribution patterns and phylogeny, with description of a new
genus from Papua New Guinea
Keywords:
Morphology, Phylogeny, Cladistic analysis, Biogeography,
Oechalinella Wang, gen. n., Oechalinella bifasciata Wang sp. nov
Abstract:
A morphological phylogenetic analysis of the tribe
Tropiduchini (Hemiptera: Tropiduchidae) is provided for 21 genera over
26 recognized species, including the new genus Oechalinella Wang, gen.
n., with a new species Oechalinella bifasciata Wang sp. nov.. Monophyly
of the tribe is well supported by male genitalia synapomorphies. Strict
consensus supports two sub-clades:
((Montrouzierana+Thymbra)+Thaumantia+) sister to (Leptovanua,
Vanua+Varma+, Daradacella). (Montrouzierana+Thymbra) clade, distributed
in New Caledonia and Papua New Guinea is well supported by 3 tegmina
synapomorphies, while the Thaumantia+ group is characterized by anal
tube and male gonostyli conformation, a distributed from Malesia to
Papuasia and west side up to central Africa. The second sub-clade is
distributed from China to Malesia, Papuasia, Southwest and Northwest
Pacific islands. Position of the genus Leptovanua remains uncertain. The
Varma+ clade is recovered in all analysis. Implied weighting analysis
placed the Varma+ lineage sister to all other genera forming a new group
(Leptovanua+ + ((Montrouzierana + Thymbra) + Thaumantia+)). Fennahs
(1982) definition of Tropiduchini is reviewed according to the
phylogenetic results and identification key to all genera is provided
with a referenced synopsis of their distribution. Globally, Tropiduchini
exhibits an inter-tropical latitudinal profile and a paradoxical bimodal
longitudinal distribution pattern in continental Africa, South-East Asia
and Pacific islands area. Distribution areas of the recovered clades
concern nearly 80% of insular taxa, confronted with the phylogenetic
results, indicate that the tribe originates probably from continental
China and evolved mainly for Papuasia by stepping-stone colonization
events, promoting subsequent insular speciations, and dispersion versus
vicariance has mainly directed the evolution of the tribe.
